Executive Summary [A68.155]



The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: (a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; (c) The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario; (d) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; (e) The five-year accident history; (f) The emergency response program; and (g) Planned changes to improve safety.



This four section report meets the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency for Prevention Program 2.  

The City of San Juan, Hidalgo County, Texas, operates as a Prevention Program 2.  Filemon Olvera, Director of Utilities for City of San Juan, is the responsible official at the facility. 



The City of San Juan Water Treatment Plant No. 1 is located at the south east corner of the intersection of Kansas and 8th Street, San Juan, Hidalgo County, Texas (north 26.186878 latitude and west -098.155037 longitude).  The City of San Juan Water Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine for disinfection. The maximum inventory for Chlorine is 4,000 and threshold quantity 2,500 lbs.  



Two one-ton containers of chlorine are stored in the facility. Only one is connected to the system at any given time.  The facility is staffed 24-hours a day and operators check the chlorination building daily. Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatus (SCBA) is stored outside chemical building located approximately 20 feet south of the chlorination system.



RMP regulations for Program 2 processes require one worst-case release scenario, estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint. The worst-case release scenario selected involv

ed the complete loss of the Chlorine to the air.  The 2,000 pounds worst-case release quantity selected represents the greatest amount held by one vessel. The RMP*Comp results indicate that the maximum distance needed for the concentration of chlorine to reach the toxic endpoint (0.0087 mg/L) as a result of a 10-minute release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine is 1.3 miles. The total potentially affected population with the entire area of the circle is estimated at 20,537 persons. 



One alternative scenario was selected for the offsite consequence analysis. The scenario selected involves the failure of the transfer hose on regulator connection. This failure results in the release of the entire contents of the containers over a period of 19 minutes. This is equivalent to a release rate of 91.6 pounds of chlorine per minute. The RMP*Comp  dispersion modeling results indicate that 0.2 miles is the maximum distance for the concentration of chlorine to reach the toxic endpoint (0.0087 mg/L) as a result of a 19 minute release of 91.6 pounds of chlorine per minute. The total potentially affected population within the entire area of the circle is estimated at 15,000. 



Population estimates are based on 2010 U.S. Census Bureau data from MARPLOT.   



A search of MARPLOT did not identify any offsite impacts of environmental receptors within the endpoint. Environmental receptors include natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, and federal wilderness areas.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 



The City of San Juan Utility Department has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases.  The program includes:  safety information on the covered chemicals, hazard reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.



The City of San Juan ensures that each employee

presently operating the Water Treatment Plant and each new employee are trained in the processes.  Each employee must have successfully reviewed operating procedures and demonstrated his/her ability to perform their duties. In addition, annual refresher training provided to each employee operating the chlorination process ensures that the employee understands and adheres to the current operation procedures of the process.  A written test is administered to ensure operators are aware of the process and safety.



The San Juan Water Treatment Plant emergency procedure addresses potential emergencies that can reasonably be expected to occur at the facility. The emergency response procedures consider dangers within the plant that may affect employees as well as dangers outside of the plant that may affect the public or the environment. 



The San Juan Water Treatment Plant personnel are not first responders, although they are trained in response techniques and will notify other first responders in the event of an accidental chlorine release. An emergency response plan is kept on-site where all employees have access to it.  The City of San Juan Fire Department is the first responder.  The City of San Juan's Fire Department may request assistance from other neighboring cities equipped with additional HAZMAT capabilities.    



The City of San Juan Water Treatment Plant posts escape plans within the facility where any person entering can see them. Facility personnel receive training in the escape plans to leave the building and to leave the area once outside the building.





Accidental Release Prevention Program        



No accidental chlorine releases have occurred at this facility. 

      

Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The City of San Juan has initiated a training program through the City's Fire Department to familiarize first responders with the Water Treatment facilities.  Our first training event consisted of the proper use of Self-Contained-Breathing-A

pparatus (SCBA) and the installation of a Chlorine Kit B on a demonstrations cylinder.  Trained Plant Operators wear the SCBA while connection/disconnection of chlorine cylinders. Plant staff continues to check the chlorine gas alarm system for proper operation.
